citation.article-title: Anaerobic degradation of indolic compounds by sulfate-reducing enrichment cultures, and description of Desulfobacterium indolicum gen. nov. spec. nov.

p.s: Desulfobacterium (De.sul'fo.bar L. pref. de from; L. noun sulfur sulfur; Gr. neut. dim. noun bakterion a small rod; M.L. neut. n. desulfobacterium a rod-shaped sulfate reducer)
Oval to rod-shaped, non-sporing stulfate reducers.
Formate; butyrate, higher fatty acids, suecinate, fumarate, malate or pyruvate are usually used as electron donors and carbon sources.
Growth on acetate or propionate is very slow.
Several species use H2 and grow autotrophically.
Aromatic compounds originating from anaerobic decomposition of amino acids may be used by a number of species.
Organic electron donors are completely oxidized to COa.
Sulfate is the common electron acceptor being reduced to sulfide.
Most isolates reduce also sulfite or thiosulfate, but not elemental sulfur or nitrate.
Obligate anaerobes that have to be cultivated in anoxic, sulfide-reduced media.
The majority of Desulfobacterium species requires vitamins and brackish or marine concentrations of NaCl and MgCl2 for optimum growth.
Cells contain cytochromes of the b- and c-type.
Carbon monoxide dehydrogenase activity is commonly observed.
The guanine + cytosine content of the DNA ranges between 41 and 48 mol%. Desulfobacterium species are widespread in brackish or marine sediments, but occur less frequently in freshwater habitats.
The type strain is D. autotrophicum.
